titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Papers of the Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibilities, Inc. (CLEPR)
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Papers of the Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibilities, Inc. (CLEPR) FA706
titlestmt.author: Arranged and described by Anneliese Ostendarp, Ford Foundation Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2016-01-06 01:09:42 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Papers of the Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibilities, Inc. (CLEPR)
did.abstract:
In 1982 CLEPR grant files were given to the Ford Foundation Archives by Maximilian W. Kempner, secretary and attorney for CLEPR as well as a member of its Board of Directors and Executive Committee.
The Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibilities, Inc. (CLEPR) was established in 1968 with a $6 million, five-year general support grant from the Ford Foundation. In 1973 CLEPR received a $5 million grant from the Ford Foundation for a second five-year period. CLEPR also received a $290,000 grant from the U.S. Department of Justice Law Enforcement Assistance and Administration program in 1970. The Council was in operation from 1968 until 1981 and was legally dissolved in 1983.
CLEPR was successor to the National Council on Legal Clinics and the Council on Education in Professional Responsibilities (both Ford Foundation-supported). Like its predecessors, its goal was to encourage the development of clinical legal education: practical lawyer-client experience for law students while under law school supervision. To this end, CLEPR gave grants to develop clinical projects for law students, to develop teaching and supervisory faculty for the programs and to advocate clinical legal education through publications and conferences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibility (CLEPR) collection consists of eighteen feet of grant files, 1968-1974. The grant files document the administration of each CLEPR grant--the proposal, terms of approval, interim, annual, and final reports, correspondence between CLEPR and the grantee, and other grant-related material. The papers also include documentation of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration (U.S. Department of Justice) grant to CLEPR for model Prosecutor/Law Student clinical programs. The papers do not contain CLEPR office files, rejected grant proposals, financial records, CLEPR Executive Committee minutes, or grant files created after 1975.

CLEPR awarded grants to law schools in the United States, Canada, and some developing countries to start or improve clinical legal education programs; to individuals for travel and study to improve clinical legal education programs; and to institutions to sponsor conferences. Specific examples include grants to: the University of Tennessee or legal services for lower-income groups with economic and business development needs, Georgetown University for support for the student-staffed public interest law center, Yale University for supervision of student-run Legal Services Organization.

The Ford Foundation Archives holds additional material related to CLEPR. "Enhancing Theory with Practice," by Lance Liebman, is a 1972 evaluation of four years of CLEPR activities (report #002165). The Ford Foundation grant to CLEPR (grant file PA68-894) contains grant correspondence, reports, evaluations and CLEPR newsletters and publications.
This register includes three appendices: an alphabetical list of CLEPR grantees (1968-74), CLEPR grantees 1975-78, and CLEPR Officers and Directors.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be restricted from scholarly research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment.
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be restricted from scholarly research at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/RAC Head of Reference.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.
Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Material more than ten years old is open for scholarly research.
Select individual files are restricted, as noted. Permission to access these files must be obtained from the Ford Foundation before scholarly access is permitted.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Because its "original order" consisted of one or more alphabetical sequences within some years, it was decided to arrange the files chronologically by grant number.

Each CLEPR grant number consists of the last two digits of the year the grant was awarded, a hyphen, and the next available number, e.g. 70-09 was the ninth grant awarded in 1970. Some grant numbers also include a mneumonic letter: J=Justice Department, F=Fellowhip. For example 72-01J was a CLEPR grant to Georgetown University for which CLEPR received grant funds from the Justice Department. In other instances the letter following the grant number, e.g. 71-34b, differentiates two grants with the same number. 71-34 was a grant given to Columbia University; 71-34b was a separate grant also given to Columbia University for a different purpose.
The dates listed for each grant file indicate the duration of the grant.

The grant file format is similar to the format of the Ford Foundation grant file: (1) grant proposal, recommendation and approval letters, (2) correspondence including interim, annual and evaluation reports, and (3) miscellaneous grant materials. Within each of these sections, items are filed in reverse chronological order.
It should be noted that some grant files are missing some of these documents.
